newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil portworkers begin 24-hr nationwide strike.
newsitem.headline: Brazil portworkers begin 24-hr nationwide strike.

text.p: Brazil's National Portworkers Federation began a 24-hour nationwide strike at 0700 local/0900 gmt on Tuesday to protest a government bill regulating inland and coastal shipping, a labour union official said.
"All port operations are stopped," said Jose Renato Rosa, general secretary of the National Portworkers Federation.
Rosa said the strike was affecting all of Brazil's 32 ports and roughly 60,000 portworkers.
It was not immediately clear to what extent the stoppage had actually halted port activity.

The Federation is protesting changes introduced to the omnibus inland and costal shipping bill which would allow port operators to use non-union personnel to load and unload cargo on ships traveling between Brazilian ports.
The bill, which was put forward by rightwing congressman Jose Carlos Aleluia, was scheduled to be voted on later today in the Lower House chamber.

"The bill directly attacks the rights of portworkers," Rosa said adding that the Federation could decide to extend the strike for a further 24 hours if the bill was not amended to satisfy union demands.
"If its not voted on today or if its not changed, the strike will continue," he said.
